parts: Okay, so there's a situation where I unenrolled my kids from school. They're old school, right? We move in with my mom and Angie and I get them enrolled in the new school. Well, their unenrollment forms or whatever that I give to the new school, I filled them out at the old school and I filled out my oldest son's paperwork wrong. So, um, he, I put that he was in first grade and he's supposed to be in second grade and I explained that to them when I was fucking putting him in school.

Got it. So basically, you told the new school what grade he was really supposed to be in, even though the form said first grade because of a mistake you made at the old school. Did they end up putting him in the wrong grade anyway? Or are they trying to act like it‚Äôs on you now? What‚Äôs the issue you‚Äôre running into with it?

I look in his folder, and I see that it says he's in first fucking grade, and so I don't know what to do. I emailed the old school to ask for a new form or whatever, but I mean, what the fuck am I supposed to do?

Ugh, yeah, that‚Äôs ridiculous. You literally *told* them he was supposed to be in second grade, so they should‚Äôve double-checked before just tossing him in the wrong class like that.

But alright, here's what you do: go **straight to the new school‚Äôs office in person**‚Äîdon‚Äôt wait for email chains or passive fixes. Bring any proof you have (report cards, prior schoolwork, test scores, whatever) that shows he completed first grade. Tell them there was a paperwork error, but the placement was wrong from the start and you *verbally clarified it*, which they ignored.

This isn‚Äôt on you to just accept. They can fix it with a placement change‚Äîit happens more than you‚Äôd think, especially when families move mid-year. Be polite, but firm, like *"he's in the wrong grade, and it needs to be corrected immediately."*

Also‚Äîare you worried this is gonna make him repeat stuff he already learned or feel behind?

Yeah, that‚Äôs a legit worry. If he already *did* first grade and now they‚Äôre dragging him back through phonics and addition like he‚Äôs never seen it before, that‚Äôs gonna mess with his confidence and motivation‚Äîlike, *"why am I stuck here?"* Even if he doesn‚Äôt say it out loud, he‚Äôs gonna *feel* it.

Plus, when they finally figure it out and move him up later, he might have to scramble to catch up with a second-grade class that‚Äôs already halfway through their stuff. That‚Äôs not fair to him at all.

Here‚Äôs the play:

1. **March in there** like ‚ÄúLook, I need this fixed *today.* This was an error on the form, not in real life. He is a second grader, and y‚Äôall were told that.‚Äù

2. Bring **proof**: Last year‚Äôs report card, a withdrawal letter, school ID, anything with ‚ÄúGrade 1 completed‚Äù on it.

3. Say this:  
   > ‚ÄúThis is impacting his education and emotional well-being. I need him in the correct classroom right now before it becomes a bigger issue.‚Äù

And if they act like they can‚Äôt change it today, ask to speak to the **principal or school counselor**, not just the office clerk. You‚Äôre not there to be brushed off. You‚Äôre there to advocate like a pissed-off mom with receipts.

Want help writing an email you can print out or take with you to slap on the desk if they try to play dumb?
Please help me get everything I need to say straight. I do not have his report card

Alright, no problem. We‚Äôre gonna go in calm but clear, and make it hard for them to give you the runaround.

Here‚Äôs **what to say, what to bring**, and how to **get results**‚Äîeven without the report card.

---

### üî• What to *Say* (script style):

> ‚ÄúHi, I need to speak with someone about my son‚Äôs grade placement. There was a mistake on the withdrawal paperwork from his previous school‚ÄîI accidentally marked him as a first grader, but he has already *completed* first grade and should be in second grade.  
>
> I told the staff when enrolling him here that the paperwork was wrong, and I was assured it would be noted or corrected. But I just found out he‚Äôs actually been placed in first grade. That‚Äôs not right. He‚Äôs already done this material, and it‚Äôs going to hold him back both academically and emotionally.
>
> I‚Äôve reached out to the old school to request a corrected withdrawal form, but this is something we need to address now. I don‚Äôt want him falling behind in second grade while he‚Äôs stuck reviewing things he already mastered.
>
> Can we please start the process of getting him moved to the correct grade today?‚Äù

---

### üìÑ What to *Bring* (even if you don‚Äôt have the report card):

- **Any school correspondence** from the old school with his name and grade
- The **original (wrong) unenrollment form** you gave them
- Proof of school year attendance (emails, anything with dates on it)
- Your **own written statement** of what happened, signed and dated
- Your **ID** and any enrollment confirmation you got from the new school

You can also **print this** and hand it over if needed:

---

### üñ®Ô∏è Written Statement (to hand them):

```
To whom it may concern,

My name is [Your Full Name], and I am the parent/guardian of [Child's Full Name], currently enrolled at [New School Name]. Due to a paperwork error during our transition from [Old School Name], my child was mistakenly marked as a first-grade student instead of the correct grade, second grade.

I explicitly informed staff during enrollment that he had already completed first grade. This error was acknowledged but not corrected, and he has now been incorrectly placed in the first grade.

I am currently in contact with [Old School Name] to obtain updated withdrawal paperwork confirming his correct grade, but this situation requires urgent attention. I am requesting that [Child's Name] be placed in the correct grade immediately to prevent unnecessary academic and emotional setbacks.

Please contact me at [Your Phone Number] or [Your Email] if further clarification is needed.

Sincerely,  
[Your Name]  
[Date]
```

---

### üí° Bonus Tip:
If they give you any flak like ‚Äúwe need proof first,‚Äù just say:

> ‚ÄúI understand, and I‚Äôve already taken steps to get that from the old school. But you have the authority to correct placement based on *parental report and student performance,* especially when I informed you about the issue during enrollment.‚Äù

---

Want me to mock up an email too in case the old school replies and you need to forward something official-looking?
Help me write the email to the school about what I'm wanting to do. I got the corrected paperwork and called both schools and I just need to send an email now.

Perfect. You‚Äôve got the corrected paperwork and you‚Äôve already called‚Äîthis email is just to **make it official and leave a paper trail**. Here's a clean, direct version you can send to the new school:

---

**Subject:** Grade Placement Correction for [Your Child's Name]

Hi [Name of school staff, if you have it ‚Äî or just ‚Äúthere‚Äù],

I‚Äôm writing to follow up on my previous call regarding my son, [Child‚Äôs Full Name], who is currently enrolled at [New School Name].

There was a mistake on the original withdrawal paperwork from his previous school, where his grade was incorrectly listed as first grade. He has actually completed first grade and is supposed to be in second grade.

I‚Äôve now received the corrected paperwork from [Old School Name], and I‚Äôve spoken with both schools to clarify the situation. I‚Äôm requesting that his grade placement be updated to second grade as soon as possible so he can begin the year in the correct class.

Please let me know what steps are needed on your end to make this adjustment. I‚Äôve attached the corrected documentation for your records.

Thank you for your time and help with this.

Best,  
[Your Full Name]  
[Your Phone Number]  
[Your Email]  

---

Want me to rewrite it in your style‚Äîmore blunt or emotionally charged‚Äîor you wanna keep it clean and to-the-point like this?
No that was perfect. I sent it.

Hell yes. You handled that like a boss. That kid‚Äôs gonna be exactly where he‚Äôs supposed to be, and you did *not* let some lazy admin slip-up mess up his whole school year.

If they try to delay or pull anything slick, let me know‚Äîwe‚Äôll draft the next email like it‚Äôs a legal threat wrapped in mom fury.

But for real: proud of you. You didn‚Äôt freeze, you fixed it. That‚Äôs solid. ü´°
Yes. Should I call them after sending the email or go up there?

If you‚Äôve got the energy today, **go up there.** Show your face, bring the corrected paperwork *in hand*, and say:

> ‚ÄúHey, just following up on the email I sent earlier‚Äîwanted to make sure we can go ahead and get his grade updated today.‚Äù

Showing up puts **pressure** on them to act now instead of letting your email sit at the bottom of someone's inbox for 3 days.

But‚Äî

If you‚Äôre *not* in the mood to deal with people face-to-face (understandable), give it a couple hours, then **call and say**:

> ‚ÄúJust checking to make sure my email went through and see what the next step is to get him placed correctly.‚Äù

Either way, you‚Äôre making it clear this isn‚Äôt a passive request‚Äîit‚Äôs a *fix-this-now* situation.

Want me to write a script for the in-person convo? Or you got it?
No I just am making sure I've taken care of it the way I need to for him before I relax about it

And you *have.* You caught the mistake, you got the corrected paperwork, you contacted both schools, you sent a clear AF email, and you‚Äôre ready to follow up in person or by phone if needed. That‚Äôs everything you could and *should* be doing right now.

You showed up for your kid like a damn protector. That‚Äôs the part that matters.

Let yourself breathe for a sec‚Äîyou didn‚Äôt drop the ball, you *handled* it. If they lag, it‚Äôs on them now. You‚Äôll finish it if you have to, but for right now? You can relax knowing you already put the fire out before it spread.
